Examples from Gairm –
[...] Shuidh e air cathair. “Tha sinn airson feadhainn de na h-òrain as aithne dhuibh a chur air clàr, gus nach teid iad air chall.” “Smaoinich,” arsa Màiri mu dheireadh, “am B.B.C. a’ tighinn thugainn a dh’ aon ghnothach.” “Thugam-sa,” ars a’ chailleach ann a seòrsa de sgriach, “thugam-sa.” Theab e innse dhaibh nach ann bho ’n Bh.B.C. a bha e mach ach cha robh e airson gnothaichean a dheanamh na bu doirbhe. [...]
[...] He sat [down] on a chair. “We are wanting to put some of the songs that you know on record, so that they are not lost.” “Just think,” said Mary eventually, “the BBC coming to us (deliberately).” “To me,” said the old woman in a kind of screech, “to me”. He nearly told them that he was not from the BBC but he did not want to make matters more complicated. [...] td. 170, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Cha robh e fhéin a’ faireachdainn uabhasach math, oir, air a’ bhàta, bha triùir dhaoine le botul uisge-bheatha agus cha robh càil air a shon ach gu feumadh e òl ’nan cuideachd. [...] An dràsda ’s a rithist shealladh Iain a-mach air an uinneig ris a’ mhuir ’s na h-eileanan. Chitheadh e aig amannan na faoileagan a’ gabhail seachad, ’s chluinneadh e an cuid sgriachail. Le an amhaichean fada caola ’s an cuirp geala biorach mar chlachan bha iad a’ cur gràin’ air. Theab e an glacadh ’s an lìonadh le uisgebeatha, na biasdan nach gabhadh sàsachadh, na clachan aosd ud, na sgòrnanan ud làn gaoith is sgadain. [...]
[...] He [John] was not feeling terribly good, because, on the boat, there were three men with a bottle of whisky and there was nothing for it but that he would have to drink in their company. [...] Now and again John would look out the window at the sea and the islands. He could see at times the gulls going past, and he could hear their screeching. With their long thin necks and their pointed white bodies like stones they disgusted him. He almost [??] caught them and filled them with whisky, the beasts that cannot be satiated, those ancient stones, those throats full of wind and herring. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Biblical examples –
[...] A nis dh’éirich righ ùr air an Eiphit, do nach b’aithne Ioseph. Agus thubhairt e r’a shluagh, Feuch, tha sluagh chloinn Israeil ni’s lìonmhoire agus ni’s cumhachdaiche na sinne. [...]
[...] Now there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph. And he said unto his people, Behold, the people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we: [...] Ecsodus I.8-9 Non-restrictive. Source: Cha b’ aithne don rìgh Ioseph.
